comment: I horrible professor, is condescending to other students and is late every class. Would be 15+ minutes late, did not lay out the expectations for lab assignments and will grade extremely harshly. Never graded anything until April so you never knew what mistakes to correct on future assignments. Worst professor I have taken.

EXTRA CREDIT!!! this is all I have to say about his class. I got 35 %,45 %,80 %,70%, and 49% (no final curve) on the final and I got an 88.5 in his class due to the extra credit. I got a private tutor after the first two tests which helped me achieve 80 and 70 on the last two tests. He's nice tho

I would not recommend it. He obviously knows the material but he teaches like the students should already know it too. He lectures for an hour straight and does not look up once. His accent can be hard to understand and he wears a mask. I only passed because of SI and outside studying. He does give lots of bonus points, though. Bland and monotone

Mr. Stollenz teaches you like he is talking to a group of people with PhDs in chemistry. I have no idea what is going on in class and Im sure that goes for the majority of my class. Do not take him if you want to keep your gpa.
rating_tags: Skip class? You won't pass.--Lots of homework--Lecture heavy

comment: Very ineffective teacher. Lecture style is extremely dry and is linear in how he expects students to learn in how he teaches. When you ask for help on a homework problem, all he does is tell you to refer to another example from the online book or his lectures. Only positives is tons of extra credit and he drops lowest test.

Prof. Stollenz isn't bad but there is nothing that makes him much better than the rest. He has plenty of extra credit opportunities and if you take advantage of them you have a good shot at doing well in the class. Before the tests he has practice tests formatted very similarly that are also for extra credit.
Offers a TON of bouns points. Hes not the worse chem 2 teacher on campus so Id recommend. However theres a ton of homework!
rating_tags: Get ready to read--EXTRA CREDIT--Lecture heavy

comment: All in all, you are going to have a ton of homework in this course. The lectures are ridiculously boring and he wastes time on material that is not on the exam. That is what I do not like. However, there are probably 220-250 bonus points offered, AKA 22-25%. So you can go from a 65 to a 90. Take for the easy A and just push through. Super boring.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Skip class? You won't pass.--Lecture heavy

comment: There is Alot of homework in this class. Lectures were very boring. Many chances for extra credit about 100 bonus points.

Gives a total of around 400 homework problems over the entire course. He does give out practice tests which totals an extra 12% of your final grade if you make 100's on them (If you have a 72 at the end of the course it would go up to a 90). However, homework takes up too much time. Overall, buddy here is a cap.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Get ready to read--Participation matters

comment: Horrible class that is not even a class. You teach yourself and cannot really get a deep understanding of the topic. He gets aggaravated when you ask questions and acts as if he does not want to be there. Do Not take this class if you want to actually learn. This class is a joke.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Get ready to read--Tough grader

comment: This class is ridiculous. I calculated it, and he gave us about 214 homework problems over the first three chapters. It is an insane amount. I have never had this much homework from a single class in my life. He does give lots of bonus points and the tests aren't that bad. I would say easy A, but way too much work. Take someone else.

His lectures aren't too bad. He spends a lot of time explaining how equations are derived, which isn't useful. He gives practice tests for all 4 exams which are used for extra credit. The practice tests are very similar to the exams. He gives ALOT of homework on Mastering. The SI sessions really helped me understand the material better.

Loved Dr. Stollenz, didn't like how he had to run the class. Pretty sure he was told what to do. Lowest test gets dropped and you'll be forced into using MasteringChemistry as directed by the Chemistry department. They have all of their professors on a tight leash and administer uninformative, cookie-cutter PowerPoints for lectures.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Lots of homework--Skip class? You won't pass.

comment: His lectures aren't very helpful but in his office hours he helps explain questions. His powerpoints don't contain a lot of information but the examples on them are used on exams. He offers PLENTY of bonus points (an entire test grade worth) and bonus on each exam, AND curves every test including the ACS final. Definitely possible to make an A.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Accessible outside class--EXTRA CREDIT

comment: Very slow talker and just as slow of a grader, but also very genuine & caring. He's the type who will give you bonus points for coming to the board to do problems in front of the class. He expects a lot, but at the same time makes sure no one fails/gets left behind. Exams are tough but fair. May not get an A, but you will pass. Take him!

Inorganic lab is very weird by nature. There are only 7 labs, but a bunch are 2-3 week labs, so it'll still take the whole semester. The very first lab write-up is a full lab report! Regarding Stollenz, he's super boring and I got like 60s-70s on all my labs, but somehow got a B at the end. His final is super easy, and he's kinda sweet.

Very tough lab grader, BUT like all the other reviews are saying, at the end of the semester he does a special curve and everyone gets an A or B. Labs are multi-week and exhausting, and his pre-lab lectures put you to sleep. However, he's a sweet guy and jokes around sometimes. Only had 1 office hour on a Friday though, so kinda hard to access.
rating_tags: Tough Grader--Skip class? You won't pass.--Caring

comment: If you're wondering why he has such a low overall rating, it's because he's awful in lecture. In lab though (inorganic lab especially), he's incredibly easy. Although he will grades labs extremely harshly (my lab grade range was 65-85), at the end of the semester he gives everyone an A or B (nothing below that). Stick it out and you'll be good!

Had him for inorganic LAB. Super sweet guy! Cons: very long pre-lab lectures, doesn't know English too well, grades at snail speed, rarely posts grades online, and grades the labs pretty harshly. Pros: his final was super easy, and at the end of the semester he literally gave everyone an A or B no matter what your grade should have been. Take him!

He isn't bad. Attend class, do the work, ask questions, and you will pass no problem. I would take him again.  He is awkward, but kind. Go to his office hours. Not a difficult professor at all. Has an accent, but it's easy to get used to. Reading the book to pass the class isn't necessary, but I encourage you to read. Inorganic chem. IS interesting
Did research with Stollenz and was sorely disappointed. We never did much actual research the whole semester. We ran 3 reactions. What a dismal experience.
His fave hobby is to confuse everyone about a subject, then give a quiz on this subject that's 40x harder than what he just talked about. Avoid.
He doesn't take student feedback well. He is not a good professor and is condescending to everyone in the class.

He drops the lowest test. There are plenty of bonuses that counts a lot. The class average was a 50.  If you did just a tad bit better than average, all your homework, all extra credit opportunities, did well on all your quizzes, then you don't need to worry. We did better than national average on ACS final even though we failed his exams.
